titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Andrew Cropsey letter 1977.669
titlestmt.author: Matthew Gorham
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection was originally processed and described as part of the project, "Uncovering the Secrets of Brooklyn's 19th Century Past: Creation to Consolidation," funded by the Council on Library and Information Resources, with additional support from The Gladys Krieble Delmas Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-12-19 19:18:43 +0000.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.abstract: A 1910 letter from Andrew G. Cropsey to a Mr. Van Cleef at the Brooklyn Hall of Records regarding a painting of the house of Nicasius DeSille, who lived in the town of New Utrecht.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Source and date of acquisition unknown. The item was formally accessioned in 1977.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection consists of a single document.

bioghist.head: Historical note
bioghist.p: The town of New Utrecht later became part of the Bay Ridge neighborhood of Brooklyn.

bioghist.head: Biographical note
bioghist.p: Andrew G. Cropsey was a lawyer practicing in Manhattan.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Andrew Cropsey letter, 1910, 1977.669, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Public Library, Center for Brooklyn History.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection was rehoused and the finding aid revised by Dee Bowers in 2023.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A letter from Andrew G. Cropsey to a Mr. Van Cleef at the Brooklyn Hall of Records regarding a painting of the house of Nicasius DeSille, who lived in the town of New Utrecht. The letter is dated May 26, 1910.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: This item is in the public domain. While many items at the Center for Brooklyn History are unrestricted, we do not own reproduction rights to all materials. Be aware of the several kinds of rights that might apply: copyright, licensing and trademarks. The researcher assumes all responsibility for copyright questions.
